'''''Amanita basii''''' is a [[mushroom]] of the genus ''[[Amanita]]''.

== Description ==

Its [[Cap (mycology)|cap]] is at around 67–152 mm wide, with a brown reddish color to "[[cadmium orange]]" becoming very intense red, "lake red" or brownish red in the center part of the cap, which is somewhat faded by the sun, in spots it's red-orange, orange-yellow to deep orange at the margin, yellow at the margin in maturity. The [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] seen in the mushroom is absent in maturity or is present when young as small white patches. Its [[flesh]] has a color ranging from butter yellow to yellowish under the cap skin, yellow in the center part and near the margin, from pale yellowish white to white elsewhere, the flesh is around 9 – 13 mm thick above the stem, and it thins evenly to the margin. The [[Gill (mycology)|gills]] are free, subcrowded, thickest close to the margin, and are around 9–12 mm broad.
The stem is 124–137 × 16–23 mm with a pale yellowish to orange color in the upper part of the stem with light yellow as the ground color. The ring is attached in the upper part, subapical, skirt-like, copious, [[biological membrane|membranous]], persistent, orange-yellow at first, becoming yellow-orange.  The saccate volva is smooth, white, with yellow tints on the inner surface, dry, [[biological membrane|membranous]], firmly attached to the stem.  The [[flesh]] is white, staining light yellow, and stuffed with moderately dense material.<ref name=Amanitaceae/> The spores measure around approximately 9.0–11.8 (8.0–18.0) × 6.1–7.5(5.5–9.0) µm and are broadly [[ellipsoid]] to [[Elongation (geometry)|elongate]] (rarely cylindric) and [[inamyloid]].  Clamps are common at bases of [[basidia]].<ref name=Amanitaceae>{{cite web | url = http://www.amanitaceae.org/index.php?Amanita%20fulva | title = ''Amanita basii''|work=Amanitaceae.org |accessdate=2016-09-18}}</ref>

Its stem is around 124–137 (12.4-13.7 cm) × 16–23 (1.6-2.3 cm) mm, with a pale yellow to orange color in the upper part of the mushroom's stem with a light yellow on the ground, becoming [[brown]] to blackish with handling, stuffed, subcylindric to [[cylindrical]], with irregular ragged patches and strands of orange-yellow felted to membranous material on the outer surface; the stem decoration becomes more intensely orange when handled. The ring is attached in the upper part, subapical, skirt-like, copious, [[biological membrane|membranous]], persistent, orange-yellow at first, becoming yellow-orange. The [[saccate]] [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] is smooth, white, with yellowish tints on the inner surface, dry, membranous, firmly attached to the stem. The [[Flesh (mycology)|flesh]] is white, staining light yellow, and stuffed with moderately [[density|dense]] material.<ref name=MushroomObserver>{{cite web | url = https://mushroomobserver.org/name/show_name/18406 | title = ''Amanita basii'' |work=Allan Rockefeller |accessdate=2016-09-20}}</ref>

=== Edibility ===

Though not that well known compared to other [[edible mushroom]] species, '' A. basii'' is considered to be edible and has a sweet taste. The odor is somewhat pleasantly fungoid.<ref name="Amanitaceae"/>

== Habitat ==

It occurs in [[pine]], [[oak]], [[fir]], and [[alder]] forests in [[Mexico]].
